learningAssessment.title: Quiz 3

lcTrueFalse.lcQuestion: The following is a good candidate for reuse: Don’t overtighten it or damage could occur.
lcTrueFalse.lcFeedbackIncorrect: The pronoun it could refer to anything, and that might affect how the sentence would be translated. It would be better to substitute a generic noun in place of it, such as the fastener.
lcTrueFalse.lcFeedbackCorrect: Right. The pronoun it makes this a poor candidate for reuse.

lcTrueFalse.lcQuestion: The following is a good candidate for reuse across publications about automobiles: In case of an emergency, move your vehicle to the side of the road, if possible.
lcTrueFalse.lcFeedbackIncorrect: The content would be reused in the same context, and does not contain pronouns that refer to something outside itself. This content is a good candidate for reuse.
lcTrueFalse.lcFeedbackCorrect: Right. Because the reuse is within the context of automobiles, and the content doesn’t use pronouns to refer to anything outside itself, it’s a good candidate for reuse.

lcSingleSelect.lcQuestion: Where should reused content be stored?

lcAnswerOption.lcAnswerContent: You can reuse content wherever it might be, just as long as it’s referred to in one of the maps in the publication where it’s being reused.
Topics that contain reusable elements should be dedicated to that purpose and should only be used as a resource rather than being published directly.

lcSingleSelect.lcFeedbackIncorrect: Even though it might be technically possible to do this, it’s not a good idea. Using dedicated warehouse topics makes it easier to manage the reuse.
lcSingleSelect.lcFeedbackCorrect: Correct. Storing your reusable elements in dedicated warehouse topics makes it easier to manage the reuse.

lcTrueFalse.lcQuestion: Using phrase elements to substitute words within sentences never causes problems for translation.
lcTrueFalse.lcFeedbackIncorrect: Not all languages follow the same rules as English. Just because the substitution works in English doesn’t mean that it will work well in other languages. And, you should assume that your content will be translated someday, even if it’s not translated today.
lcTrueFalse.lcFeedbackCorrect: Right. You can’t assume that other languages work the same way as English but with different words. It’s easy to unintentionally garble translated text when you use DITA reuse mechanisms to change parts of a sentence.
